title: Which film will win the 2019 Academy Award for Best Picture?
preds: This one was a bit tough, as I have only seen 3 of the movies nominated.  Time magazine had an interesting article on predicting this.  According to their algorithm, 3 main pieces of info can be useful to providing a good guesstimate here:  1. was the film also nominated for Best Director?  2. was it also nominated for best editing?  3. did it win top honors from the Director's Guild of America (announced before Oscars)? Romo meets criteria #1 and #3 listed above.  According to the article, the Dir's Guild award can greatly enhance the odds of winning.  The second criteria, which Roma did not meet, has a strong correlation to winning Best Pic.  The article mentions that the algorithm used does not take into account Hollywood internal politics and bias.  Working against Roma is the fact that the industry may not want to see a Netflix film win this award.   My second choice to win is Spike Lee's BlacKKKlansman.  I really enjoyed this movie, and feel this may be Spike's chance to win, much like Martin Scorsese finally got his deserved victory with The Departed. This film also meets criteria #1 and #3 above, but not #2. Working against this film, is the many enemies Spike likely has in Hollywood - politics in play again. My sentimental favorite is Black Panther, but I just don't see a Marvel film getting the nod.  I know Vice and The Favorite, also are strong contenders (and they meet criteria #1 and #3), however I just don't know too much about them. http://time.com/5533849/oscars-academy-awards-prediction-best-picture/

To undercut its chances as a "contender" The Green Book has been vilified by the worst forms of mendacity and effete critques by pundits and academics who follow culture and cinema. Its the Hollywoodland version of "The Night of the Long Knives." One particular meme that has gotten street cred is that The Green Book does not offer an accurate representation of the African-American "experience" today. But the film is not about "today."  Nobody said anything about the incipient racism a few years ago when the film "The Express" (about late Syracuse University Heisman winner Ernie Davis) was showcased when  he traveled to Dallas in the Jim Crow south to play against Texas in the Cotton Bowl. Davis went to Dallas at the same time Don Shirley was touring the south. The PR ugliness we are seeing now could be just a spoonful of what might happen when presidential campaigns on behalf of candidates "of color" or "hispanic" or "democratic socialists" gain momentum.  Add the "Smollett Conundrum" to the mix and there's likely to be a big demand a lot of "Tony Lip's"... who can morph out of the "muscle" business and into "PR"... but they might come from places other than the Bronx...
Rough averages of THR and Predictwise

Completely opinionated rambling:
. A Star is Born should have done better but for Cooper’s rant in NYT. (I really enjoyed it though)
. Green Book (based on true story) not well received by family of main character
. The Favourite while likely good lacked broad appeal
. Black Panther worthy of some awards but best picture not one of them
. Roma (Netflix) well received, may be good indicator for upcoming streaming services, and bit of a snub for Trump (which many in industry would like ).
https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/oscars-2019-math-predicts-roma-best-picture-win-1188181 Will update with mean of these and Predictwise's when the latter posts forecasts.

In order of current Metacritic scores:
 - Roma 96%
 - The Favourite 90% (I've heard good things about this one)
 - Black Panther 88%
 - A Star Is Born 88%
 - BlacKkKlansman 83%
 - Green Book 69%
 - Vice 61%
 - Bohemian Rhapsody 49% (a friend said it was good) I haven't seen all of these films, but Roma, The Favourite, A Star Is Born, Green Book and Bohemian Rhapsody seem like the sorts of films I can imagine winning this sort of award; I'll move them to the top of my list.  On the flip side Black Panther is a super-hero action movie, which almost surely rules it out so I'm putting it at the bottom (this last point differs significantly from the crowd forecast - am I missing something?)
Adjusted to combine two sources which are not based on my personal taste in anyway
The most outside of outside views.
